activity.reader: Changing Lifestyles Contribute to Obesity Around the world, more than one billion adults are overweight, with at least 300 million of these classified as obese. While this used to be a problem primarily in the West, the number of obese and overweight Asians has been rising dramatically. As populations move from the countryside to the big cities, Asians are eating fattier foods and living more sedentary lifestyles. In Asian cities, processed foods rich with sugar and saturated fats are often the most convenient and the cheapest. Ice cream, cookies, soft drinks, and potato chips—once all foreign foods—are now as common in Asia as they are in the West. Statistics show that people are eating more meat, oils, and fats and less rice and vegetables. At the same time, Asians are getting less physical exercise. As populations transition from agricultural jobs in the countryside to less physically demanding work in urban areas, lifestyles have become less active. People use public transportation instead of walking and use technology to make housework easier. In the past, it was common for children to spend much of their free time outside, playing with other children. In urban areas, however, there is less space for physical activity and children spend most of their free time inside, playing video games and watching TV. Increases in health problems related to these lifestyle changes are beginning to be seen. In fact, studies show that six out of ten deaths in Asia are due to diseases that may be linked to obesity-- heart attacks, diabetes, high blood pressure, and some forms of cancer.

pair.question: There are more than one billion overweight adults in Asia.
Obesity is a new health problem in Asia.
Asians are eating foods today that they didn’t use to eat.
It’s easy to find Western snacks like ice cream and cookies in Asia.
In Asia, processed foods rich with sugar and saturated fats are expensive.
In Asian cities, people walk less because they can use buses and trains to get where they need to go.
